snippet: Somalia, a nation where 40 percent of the population depends on remittances from abroad, is alarmed by Barclays’s plans to suspend the accounts of some money transfer services.
abstract: British bank Barclays, fearing run-in with regulators over potentially abetting financing of terrorists or money laundering, plans to suspend accounts of several money transfer companies used to send money to accounts in developing countries; decision could spell disaster for those who depend on remittances from family members living abroad, especially in Somalia, country without functioning banking system.

byline.contributor: Mohammed Ibrahim contributed reporting from Mogadishu, Somalia.

lead_paragraph: Somalia, a nation where 40 percent of the population depends on remittances from abroad, is alarmed by Barclays’s plans to suspend the accounts of some money transfer services.

headline.main: Somalis Face a Snag in Lifelines From Abroad
headline.print_headline: Somalis Face a Snag in Lifelines From Abroad
